title: How I Finally Memorized Modifier Ordering in Compose
description: For the longest time, I proudly had no idea of how Modifier ordering works, and would just guess and then guess again when something didn't look quite right. Here's how I finally ended up remembering how the ordering works.

title: Building a macOS screen saver in Kotlin
description: This article documents how I created my own custom screen saver for macOS, built almost entirely in Kotlin, using the powers of Kotlin Multiplatform compiled to macOS. Join me for a tale of Kotlin success and macOS failures.

title: Episode 211: Rules about performance tools
description: In this episode Chet, Romain and Tor chat with Shai Barack about how the Android platform team studies performance and understands system health - and what is system health anyway? We talk about measuring performance, deciding trade-offs, and our favorite tools such as Perfetto, Compiler Explorer, and Android Studio's Memory Profiler. ¬† Chapters: Intro (00:00) System health (0:27) Efforts to make apps more efficient (3:35) Telemetry data (5:59) Trade offs between long battery life and good performance (8:21) Scheduling groups (10:38) Static drain (13:32) Collaborating with App developers vs operating system (19:10) High refresh rates (23:26) Reach vs engagement (32:02) What tools does your team use to optimize performance? (34:10) Godbolt.org (37:09) Demystifying (39:39) The best tools are multi-player (43:52) R8 or R-Not? (45:42) Optimizing for feature sets (48:05) Tools, not Rules (50:08) What are the tools I should be aware of as an app developer looking to upscale performance? (54:36) Allocation tracker (55:37) Open source tools (57:08) Useful resources for devs to understand various tools (59:04) Final thoughts (1:06:19) Links: Compiler Explorer ‚Üí https://goo.gle/3Zbq6DV¬† Perfetto ‚Üí https://goo.gle/3OtD3UK and https://goo.gle/3B3S3p5¬† Tools, not Rules¬† ‚Üí https://goo.gle/416CyY7¬† ¬† Shai:¬† Romain: @romainguy,¬†threads.net/@romainguy, romainguy@androiddev.social Tor: threads.net/@tor.norbye and tornorbye@androiddev.social Chet: @chethaase,¬†threads.net/@chet.haase, and chethaase@androiddev.social ¬† Catch videos on YouTube ‚Üí https://goo.gle/adb-podcast¬†¬† Subscribe to Android Developers¬† ‚Üí https://goo.gle/AndroidDevs
author: Android Developers

title: Episode 210: Studio Jewelry
description: In this episode Chet, Romain and Tor chat with Sebastiano about how the Android Studio team builds UIs. We talk about how Compose for Desktop is used in parts of Android Studio and how the Compose Markdown renderer available in the Jewel library makes Studio Bot tick. ¬† Chapters: Intro (00:00) Android Dev UX team (00:39) What kind of libraries and languages are used to build Android studio? (1:52) Swing (2:53) Reactive and declarative programming models (8:25) SKIA for Kotlin (10:01) Jetpack Compose widgets (11:54) Jewel (13:07) Text rendering across platforms (15:51) Differences in behaviors (17:40) Support for markdown files (20:26) What is markdown? (21:25) Swing and html (25:45) Selection handling in StudioBot (28:46) Boosting productivity with Compose (30:40) Standalone vs plugin artifacts (34:29) The difference between Jewel & Swing (35:30) HTML vs Markdown (39:31) Markdeep (41:53) Jewel's Markdown API (43:46) Where to find Jewel? (46:54) Sebastiano‚Äôs podcast - Code with the Italians (47:34) Final thoughts (49:13) ¬† Links: Jetpack Compose Compose Multiplatform, for Desktop¬† Jewel Jewel Markdown Renderer ¬† Sebastiano: ‚Äã‚Äãhttps://github.com/rock3r, https://codewiththeitalians.it/ Romain: @romainguy,¬†threads.net/@romainguy, romainguy@androiddev.social Tor: threads.net/@tor.norbye and tornorbye@androiddev.social Chet: @chethaase,¬†threads.net/@chet.haase, and chethaase@androiddev.social ¬† Catch videos on YouTube ‚Üí https://goo.gle/adb-podcast¬†¬† Subscribe to Android Developers¬† ‚Üí https://goo.gle/AndroidDevs

title: 254 - 8√ó faster 5√ó memory savings with Dan Rusu‚Äôs Immutable Arrays
description: In this episode, discover how Dan Rusu‚Äôs pods4k Immutable Arrays library can deliver 2‚Äì8√ó speed boosts and 5√ó lower memory usage in Kotlin/Android apps. We first revisit the fundamentals of autoboxing/unboxing and immutability to understand their impact on performance. Then we hear from Dan himself on his library, motiviations for building it, how the benchmarks were calculated and much much more. Our grand finale episode for 2024. Hope you enjoy it!Full Shownotes at https://fragmentedpodcast.com/episodes/254.Show NotesImmutable Arrays on githubImmutability episode #66 on Immutability with Ryan HarterJMH - Java Microbenchmark HarnessImmutable Arrays Benchmarks page for Immutable Arrays (pods4k)Dan's post - Kotlin avoids entire categories of Java defectsK2 compilerDan RusuWebsitepods4k github discussionsContact usfragmentedpodcast.comContact usYoutubeKaushik:kau.sh (links to everything)ThreadsBlueskyYoutube@kaushikgopalDisclaimer: Links shared might be affiliate links. They help support the production of Fragmented. Thank you for your support.
author: Dan Rusu, Kaushik Gopal

title: 253 - logcat - a new look at logging with Piwai from Square
description: Kaushik looks at a new logging library from Square called logcat. He starts by seeing how the popular Timber library does it along with the benefits. He then interviews Pierre-Yves Ricau (Piwai) of Square, the creator of logcat, to explore its origins and advantages.You can find the full shownotes over at fragmentedpodcast.com.Show NotesTimberlogcatMotivations in READMECompiler plugin issuePlayground android app demonstrating logcatbitdrift.ioDesign of everyday thingsPrevious episode #191 on loggingContact Piwai:WebsiteBlueskyContactYou can find us on a few places:fragmentedpodcast.comContact usYoutubeKaushik:kau.sh (links to everything)ThreadsBlueskyYoutube@kaushikgopalDisclaimer: Links shared might be affiliate links. title: Android Weekly Issue #658
description: Articles & Tutorials Sponsored Genius Scan SDK: a document scanner in your app Embed a reliable document scanner with OCR in your app, enabling your customers to capture high-quality, legible documents that you can process effortlessly. Hundreds of companies and millions of users trust the Genius Scan technology. Supports Android, iOS, and cross-platform frameworks. Using new Camera extensions API by Victor Brandalise Victor Brandalise explores the new Camera Extensions API, highlighting its support for advanced features like Night and Bokeh modes through Camera2 and CameraX. Collection Processing Guessing Game! Marcin Moskala tests your understanding of Kotlin collection processing. Widgets with Glance: Displaying images Katie Barnett explains how to incorporate images into Android widgets using Jetpack Glance, while ensuring efficient background image loading and proper state handling. Jetpack Compose and Edge-to-Edge on Android 15 Dobri Kostadinov looks at how Android 15‚Äôs edge-to-edge feature impacts Jetpack Compose development. Performance Class helps Google Maps deliver premium experiences Nevin Mital takes a look at how Google Maps was able to tailor a feature launch to best fit each device with Media Performance Class. Apps adopt Transformer to support more performant media editing Caren Chang discusses how the Jetpack Media3 library‚Äôs Transformer module offers reliable and high-performance APIs for media transcoding and editing, enabling operations like trimming, applying video effects, and format conversion. Kotlin Design Patterns - Part 3 In this third installment, Ignacio Carri√≥n covers Memento, Command, Visitor, Chain of Responsibility, and Mediator patterns. Using SVGs on Canvas with Compose Multiplatform Eevis Panula demonstrates how to convert SVG images into paths for use in Compose‚Äôs Canvas, providing flexibility in rendering vector graphics across Compose Multiplatform. Running Specific Android UI Tests using TestParameterInjector via a Regex Sam Edwards sheds light on the relatively uncommon tests_regex instrumentation argument, which allows tests to be run based on a regular expression. The Power of SKIE Subplugins Tadeas Kriz shows how to generate Swift code for your Kotlin Multiplatform project using SKIE subplugins. Place a sponsored post Advertise your Android dev course to over 80k readers Libraries & Code Jetpack-Compose-preview-creator An Android Studio plugin to quickly create jetpack compose preview functions lumo-ui A Gradle plugin for generating Compose UI components through a CLI. It provides customizable and ready-to-use components that you can copy-paste into your projects. News Android Studio Ladybug Feature Drop is Stable! Read on to learn more about all the updates, quality improvements, and new features across your key workflows in Android Studio Ladybug Feature Drop. Android Developers Blog: Media3 1.5.0 ‚Äî what‚Äôs new? Kristina Simakova announces the release of Media3 1.5.0, introducing features such as motion photo support in Transformer, faster image encoding, a new IAMF decoder, and much more! Videos & Podcasts KotlinPoet with Egor Andreevich Nicola Corti interviews Egor Andreevich about KotlinPoet, a library developed by Square for generating Kotlin code. Functional Programming in Kotlin for Android Developers Delve into the world of functional programming and its applications in Kotlin. Challenges of opportunities of operating live games (Playtime 2024) An engaging conversation with prominent game partners about the current obstacles their businesses are facing across acquisition, engagement, monetization and market expansion. Top 5 Updates From Firebase for December 2024 December 2024: New App Hosting Emulator, AI Monitoring preview, Flutter support for SPM, and more! 5 Things You MUST Do Before Deploying Your App to Google Play Philipp Lackner teaches about 5 things you should definitely not forget about before deploying your app to Google Play. What are all of those Kotlin function types for? Dave Leeds looks at the surprising number of function types in Kotlin and what they are used for. Exploring Podcast RSS Feeds with Lamberto Basti! In this episode, explore the fascinating world of podcast RSS feeds with Lamberto Basti Compose Performance for Us Humans ‚Äî Live with Tom√°≈° Mlynariƒç! Coding with the Italians goes live with Tom√°≈° Mlynariƒç to learn about Compose performance. Specials Follow us on BlueSky We're there as well!

title: Android Weekly Issue #657
description: Android Weekly Updates Follow us on BlueSky We're there as well! Articles & Tutorials Sponsored Multi-Layered Mobile App Protection Attackers constantly find ways to reverse engineer, tamper with, or clone apps, putting sensitive data and revenue streams at risk. Join our webinar to unlock insights into how a multi-layered protection approach adapts with every build to neutralize mobile app threats. Register now. Getting Started with CameraX in Jetpack Compose Jolanda Verhoef shows how to integrate the camera-compose APIs in your app and some of the delightful UI experiences that integration with Compose unlocks. How modifiers order affects Compose UI appearance Marcin Moska≈Ça explains with clear examples how Compose UI modifiers work. Sponsored Advertise your Android dev course to over 80k readers We reach out to more than 80k Android developers around the world, every week, through our email newsletter and social media channels. Advertise your Android development course! FilterChip Dropdown selector in Jetpack Compose Manpreet Kunnath creates a FilterChip dropdown selector in Jetpack Compose. Top 3 Most Common Animations You Can Use in Your Jetpack Compose Project Enhance your app‚Äôs user experience with Dobri Kostadinov's simple and effective animation techniques in Jetpack Compose. Tap to focus: Mastering CameraX Transformations in Jetpack Compose Jolanda Verhoef teaches using the Compose gesture system, graphics, and coroutines to implement a visual tap-to-focus. Understanding SOLID Principles with Kotlin Examples Ignacio Carri√≥n looks at how the SOLID principles form the foundation for building robust and scalable software. Android Dynamic Animated SVGs (with Lottie Dynamic Properties) Paul Blundell explains Lottie Dynamic Properties, a way of controlling different parts of your animation at runtime. Compose Design Systems: Have a Plan Mark Murphy considers using Material's design system for Compuse UI versus building your own. (Trying to) take notes from the lock screen Thomas K√ºnneth examines the NOTES role in Android 14 which supports the note-taking feature and increases productivity of Android tablets. Mastering Kotlin Coroutine Channels in Android: From Basics to Advanced Patterns Ioannis Anifantakis shows how using the channel type that suits your use case helps to create robust, scalable Android apps free from callback spaghetti. Client is King! Kotlin Multiplatform architecture for native UI ‚Äî Part 1 In this first post, Benedict Pregler gives an overview of the cross-platform workflow architecture and what the API on the clients look like. Libraries & Code aspecto Aspecto is a grid layout that perfectly preserves each item's aspect ratio for the Jetpack Compose / Compose Multiplatform. News Building a better smart home Google is making it easier for developers to create amazing smart home experiences for users, and for those users to enjoy seamless connectivity and interoperability across all their devices. Build the future of home with Google Home APIs The Home APIs are now in Public Developer Beta for Android Videos & Podcasts Koin just Got Better! Configuration Navigation Simplified Koin just Got Better! Configuration Navigation Simplified Camera & Media | Spotlight Week To help you enhance Android Camera and Media experiences to be even more delightful for your users, this week we will be kicking off the Camera and Media Spotlight week! How to Encrypt DataStore On Android - Full Guide Philipp Lackner teaches how to encrypt the content of DataStore Preferences, for example to safely store authentication tokens. Media & Camera experiences | Android Build Time In this episode of Android Build Time, Christopher Cartland is joined by Caren Chang and Jordan de Hoog to discuss Media API insights. We fixed an inconsistency in Kotlin (non-local break & continue) Try the non-local break and continue feature today! Learn on how to enable it in Kotlin 2.1. What's new in Android Studio Ladybug Learn what's new in the stable release of Android Studio Ladybug Feature Drop (2024.2.2)!

title: SimpleCamera
description: Simple Camera is a library that allows you to use cameras in a simplified, easy, fast and effective way. It contains CameraX as an internal library. It simplifies the camera features used by CameraX and provides ease of use with a single library. As updates come on the CameraX side, the library will try to stay up to date. Missing features will be added soon. Like video capturing.

title: EML viewer tools for different platforms
description: In the digital age, where email communication is paramount, handling various email formats becomes essential. Among these formats, EML (Email Message Format) files are widely used. EML files contain email messages and attachments, and viewing them efficiently across different platforms can be a challenge. This article explores the diverse landscape of EML viewer tools available for different platforms, aiding users in seamlessly accessing and managing their email content. The post EML viewer tools for different platforms appeared first on Universal Accessibility.
author: admgoobar

title: Viewing attachments in EML files
description: In the digital age, email communication plays a pivotal role in both personal and professional spheres. The exchange of information often involves attachments, which enhance the message‚Äôs content and functionality. Among the various file formats used in email correspondence, EML files are prominent. Understanding how to view attachments within EML files is essential for efficient... The post Viewing attachments in EML files appeared first on Universal Accessibility.

title: The pursuit of fast feedback loops
description: Sebastian Sellmair from JetBrains recently showed off a prototype of hot-reloading Compose UI code for deploying changes without rebuilding the project. It looks exciting and I want it to succeed. At the same time, I‚Äôve learned to be cautiously optimistic about hot-reload solutions. The dream of hot-reloadable android code is old ‚Äî and frankly, cold. [‚Ä¶] The post The pursuit of fast feedback loops appeared first on Saket Narayan.

title: Building a sub-sampling image viewer for Compose UI
description: How do you display a 100mb image on Android without running into OutOfMemoryError? You can‚Äôt. But you can cheat. For years Android developers have used Dave Morrissey‚Äôs excellent library, subsampling-scale-image-view for displaying large bitmaps with deep zoom. It optimizes memory usage by loading lower resolution bitmaps whenever possible and avoiding loading parts of the original [‚Ä¶] The post Building a sub-sampling image viewer for Compose UI appeared first on Saket Narayan.
